channel.title: INtopBackup
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INtopBackup, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: How one country has become a top destination for hair transplants
item.description: With more than 1 million people going to Turkey for the procedure every year, hair transplants are transforming men's scalps — and vanity. But not eve...

item.title: Illinois and Chicago sue the Trump administration over National Guard deployment
item.description: The parties are asking a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending to Illinois any guard ...

item.title: A bold doctor sent her kids away and helped beat one of the world's deadliest viruses
item.description: A year ago, Rwanda faced its first outbreak of Marburg virus. Dr. Tsion Firew remembers how scared she was — and how that didn't stop her from playing...

item.title: A major census test begins recruiting workers as some warn about delays
item.description: The Census Bureau is looking for temporary workers to carry out next year's major field test of the 2030 census in six states, as the national head co...

item.title: Judge blocks deployment of National Guard to Oregon. And, the Supreme Court's new term
item.description: A judge issues an order to stop Trump's latest attempt to deploy the National Guard to Oregon. And, the Supreme Court opens a new term with justices t...

item.title: ICE ad blitz aims to lure local law enforcement officers to join Trump mass deportation efforts
Republicans and Democrats at an impasse as government shutdown enters sixth day
item.description: Republican and Democratic lawmakers have provided few public signs of meaningful negotiations to break an impasse on reopening the federal government ...

item.title: France in fresh political crisis as PM Lecornu quits after 26 days
item.description: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.

item.title: Kilmar Abrego Garcia back in court as Trump administration pushes for deportation
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the man mistakenly deported to El Salvador in March, is back in a Maryland court Monday as his legal team tries to avert his dep...

item.title: Sudan militia leader convicted of war crimes during Darfur war
item.description: Ali Kushayb led the Janjaweed, a group whose campaign of terror led to hundreds and thousands of deaths.

item.title: Senate set to reconvene as government shutdown continues into second week
item.description: The government shutdown entered its sixth day on Monday with no signs of an imminent resolution. Follow live updates here.

item.title: Judge blocks Trump from sending troops from California to Portland
item.description: The decision late on Sunday comes a day after the same judge barred the deployment of troops from the state of Oregon.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects appeal from Ghislaine Maxwell, imprisoned former girlfriend of Jeffrey Epstein
Democrats and Republicans still trading blame as government shutdown enters Day 6
item.description: Democrats and Republicans are continuing to trade blame over the government shutdown that began last Tuesday. Senate lawmakers are expected to vote Mo...

item.title: Foreclosures are surging as U.S. homeowners grapple with rising costs
item.description: A growing number of Americans, squeezed by inflation and elevated interest rates, face the risk of losing their home in foreclosure.

item.title: US Supreme Court rejects Ghislaine Maxwell appeal in Epstein case
item.description: The British socialite is serving a 20-year prison sentence on sex-trafficking charges related to former boyfriend Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Skydiving instructor killed after falling without parachute in Nashville
item.description: The skydiver fell after becoming separated from his student and safety equipment.

item.title: Fishermen in Caribbean fear for their lives and jobs amid U.S. strikes
item.description: Fishermen in Trinidad and Tobago are fearing that a U.S. military strikes in the Caribbean could kill them and their livelihoods.
